sections.title: Music & Entertainment Questions
sections.description: Test your knowledge of classic entertainment!

questions.label: What was Elvis Presley's famous nickname?

options.label: The King of Rock and Roll
options.feedback: Correct! Elvis was crowned 'The King of Rock and Roll' and remains one of the most influential cultural icons of the 20th century.

options.label: The Boss
options.feedback: That's Bruce Springsteen! Elvis was 'The King of Rock and Roll.'

options.label: The Duke
options.feedback: That was a nickname for John Wayne! Elvis was known as 'The King of Rock and Roll.'

options.label: The Chairman of the Board
options.feedback: That's Frank Sinatra! Elvis was 'The King of Rock and Roll.'

questions.label: In what year did The Beatles appear on The Ed Sullivan Show, launching 'Beatlemania' in America?

options.feedback: Close, but that's when they released 'Love Me Do' in the UK. Their Ed Sullivan appearance was in 1964!
Correct! February 9, 1964 - over 73 million people watched The Beatles perform on Ed Sullivan. It was a cultural phenomenon!
By 1966, The Beatles were already huge! Their Ed Sullivan debut was in 1964.
That's after their touring days ended. Their Ed Sullivan breakthrough was in 1964!

questions.label: Which iconic TV show starred Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz?

options.label: I Love Lucy
options.feedback: Correct! 'I Love Lucy' (1951-1957) was groundbreaking television and remains one of the most beloved sitcoms of all time.

options.label: The Lucy Show
options.feedback: Close! 'The Lucy Show' came later (1962-1968). The original with Desi was 'I Love Lucy.'

options.label: Here's Lucy
options.feedback: That was her third show (1968-1974). The original with Desi Arnaz was 'I Love Lucy.'

options.label: The Honeymooners
options.feedback: That was Jackie Gleason's show! Lucille Ball starred in 'I Love Lucy' with Desi Arnaz.

questions.label: Which city was the home of Motown Records, the legendary soul and R&B label?

options.label: Chicago
options.feedback: Chicago had great blues and soul, but Motown was founded in Detroit by Berry Gordy!

options.label: Detroit
options.feedback: Correct! Detroit was 'Hitsville USA' - home to The Supremes, Marvin Gaye, Stevie Wonder, The Temptations, and so many legends!

options.label: Memphis
options.feedback: Memphis had Stax Records (also legendary!), but Motown was based in Detroit.

options.label: New York
options.feedback: Many Motown artists performed in New York, but the label was founded and based in Detroit!

questions.label: The series finale of M*A*S*H (1983) became the most-watched TV episode in U.S. history. How many people tuned in?

options.label: 50 million
options.feedback: Even bigger! Over 105 million viewers watched the M*A*S*H finale - still one of the most-watched episodes ever.

options.label: 75 million
options.feedback: Close, but it was even more! Over 105 million viewers watched the M*A*S*H finale.

options.label: 105 million
options.feedback: Correct! 105.9 million viewers watched 'Goodbye, Farewell and Amen' on February 28, 1983. It was a cultural moment!

options.label: 125 million
options.feedback: Not quite that high, but close! 105.9 million viewers watched - still one of the most-watched TV episodes ever.

questions.label: Johnny Carson hosted The Tonight Show for how many years?

options.label: 20 years
options.feedback: He went even longer! Johnny Carson hosted The Tonight Show for an incredible 30 years (1962-1992).

options.label: 25 years
options.feedback: Close! Johnny Carson actually hosted The Tonight Show for 30 years (1962-1992).

options.label: 30 years
options.feedback: Correct! Johnny Carson hosted The Tonight Show from 1962 to 1992 - 30 years of late-night laughs and legendary interviews!

options.label: 35 years
options.feedback: Almost, but not quite! Johnny Carson hosted The Tonight Show for 30 years (1962-1992).

questions.label: What year was the legendary Woodstock Music Festival?

options.feedback: That was the Summer of Love in San Francisco! Woodstock came two years later in 1969.
Correct! August 15-18, 1969 in Bethel, New York. 'Three days of peace and music' that defined a generation!
Close, but Woodstock was two years earlier - August 1969!
That's when the Vietnam War ended. Woodstock was in August 1969!

questions.label: Which actor starred in 'Saturday Night Fever' (1977), launching the disco craze?

options.label: John Travolta
options.feedback: Correct! John Travolta's iconic white suit and dance moves made 'Saturday Night Fever' a cultural phenomenon and launched disco into the mainstream!

options.label: Richard Gere
options.feedback: Richard Gere had his own musical moment in 'Chicago' (2002), but John Travolta starred in 'Saturday Night Fever!'

options.label: Sylvester Stallone
options.feedback: Stallone was boxing in 'Rocky' that same year! John Travolta danced his way to stardom in 'Saturday Night Fever.'

options.label: Al Pacino
options.feedback: Pacino was doing dramatic roles in the 70s. John Travolta was the disco king in 'Saturday Night Fever!'

questions.label: What was the first music video ever played on MTV when it launched in 1981?

options.label: Video Killed the Radio Star by The Buggles
options.feedback: Correct! 'Video Killed the Radio Star' at 12:01 AM on August 1, 1981. The perfect choice to launch the music video revolution!

options.label: Thriller by Michael Jackson
options.feedback: Thriller came later (1983) and was groundbreaking! But the first video was 'Video Killed the Radio Star' by The Buggles.

options.label: You Better Run by Pat Benatar
options.feedback: Pat Benatar was the second video played! The first was 'Video Killed the Radio Star' by The Buggles.

options.label: In the Air Tonight by Phil Collins
options.feedback: Great song, but the first MTV video was 'Video Killed the Radio Star' by The Buggles!

questions.label: Which city did Frank Sinatra sing about in his signature song?

options.label: Chicago
options.feedback: He sang 'Chicago (That Toddlin' Town)' too, but his signature song was about New York, New York!

options.label: New York
options.feedback: Correct! 'New York, New York' became Sinatra's signature song and an anthem for the city. 'If I can make it there, I'll make it anywhere!'

options.label: Los Angeles
options.feedback: Sinatra lived in LA, but his signature song was 'New York, New York!'

options.label: Las Vegas
options.feedback: Sinatra was synonymous with Vegas, but his signature song was 'New York, New York!'
